body:
Comment 2: 
"However, I have seen it used countless times in practice. (For example, try a
Google search with a space in it.) A quick survey of urlencode functions present in
other languages demonstrates they all convert spaces to '+'."

That's a very poorly argued case.

If we search Google for the phrase "countless times in practice", we see something
similar to:

http://www.google.com/search?q=countless+times+in+practice&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8&aq=t&rls=com.ubuntu:en-US:official&client=firefox-a

The spaces separating the words in the query have been replaced by plus (+) signs, as
per the HTML specification (application/x-www-form-urlencoded).

HTML 4.01 Specification: 17.13.4 Form content types
http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/interact/forms.html#h-17.13.4.1

The enctype attribute of the FORM element specifies the content type used to encode
the form data set for submission to the server. User agents must support the content
types listed below. Behavior for other content types is unspecified.

Please also consult the section on escaping ampersands in URI attribute values.

application/x-www-form-urlencoded  

This is the default content type. Forms submitted with this content type must be
encoded as follows:

1. Control names and values are escaped. Space characters are replaced by `+', and
then reserved characters are escaped as described in [RFC1738], section 2.2:
Non-alphanumeric characters are replaced by `%HH', a percent sign and two hexadecimal
digits representing the ASCII code of the character. Line breaks are represented as
"CR LF" pairs (i.e., `%0D%0A').

2. The control names/values are listed in the order they appear in the document. The
name is separated from the value by `=' and name/value pairs are separated from each
other by `&'.
